School of Environment and Energy South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 China Graphical abstract A series of Pt/Mn3O4 catalysts were synthesized and applied for the catalytic oxidation of toluene. Toluene-TPD, toluene-TPSR and in-situ DRIFTS manifested that toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R catalyst might follow the Mars–van Krevelen mechanism and the pathway of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R was possible toluene → benzoate → carbonate → CO2. The lattice oxygen species on the surface of catalysts was directly involved in the oxidation of toluene and played an important role in the formation of key intermediate such as carbonate, resulting in the difference of the reaction mechanism and pathway between Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C. In addition, the degradation of the surface carbonate was demonstrated to be the rate-controlling step at 180℃ to 200℃. With the aim to elucidate the roles of different oxygen species, the catalytic oxidation of toluene over Pt/Mn3O4 synthesized by a facile reduction method was investigated. Compared with the Pt/Mn3O4-C using the commercial Mn3O4 as the support, Pt/Mn3O4-R was found to possess more surface oxygen vacancies, exhibit better redox properties and dispersion of platinum particles, leading to its higher activity for toluene oxidation (T90 = 183 ℃). Through toluene-TPD, toluene-TPSR and in-situ DRIFTS, it was found that toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R catalyst might follow the Mars–van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism and the pathway of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R was possible toluene → benzoate → carbonate → CO2. The lattice oxygen species on the surface of catalysts was directly involved in the oxidation of toluene and played an important role in the formation of key intermediate such as carbonate, resulting in the difference of the reaction mechanism and pathway between Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C. In addition, the degradation of the surface carbonate was demonstrated to be the rate-controlling step at 180℃ to 200℃. Keywords Toluene Catalytic oxidation In-situ DRIFTS Toluene-TPSR Surface lattice oxygen 1 Introduction Since 2015, air quality has shown a trend of continuous improvement in China, but the ozone problem is still severe [1]. A large number of studies have revealed that reducing VOCs (volatile organic compounds) emissions is one of the most efficient strategies to control tropospheric ozone [2,3]. Numerous methods have been applied for degradation of VOCs, including physical adsorption [4,5], plasma technology [6], photocatalysis [7,8], and catalytic oxidation [9,10]. Among them, catalytic combustion is regarded as one of the most promising means for VOCs removal due to its high efficiency and less harmful byproducts [11,12]. The efficient catalyst at low temperature have become the key to the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. Noble-metal-based catalysts have always been widely used in the field of VOCs catalytic oxidation because of their excellent low-temperature catalytic efficiency [13,14]. Among them, supported Pt catalysts have received extensive attention due to their outstanding catalytic activity [15]. Numerous studies have been reported on controlling the particle size of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) and the proportion of Pt° species to enhance the catalytic properties and reduce the usage of Pt [16–18]. Furthermore, it is found that the support would also play significant roles in the catalytic performance. Therefore, much attention has been paid to designing and synthesizing supports of different types and structures [19,20]. Generally, the supports can be summarized into two types according to their reaction activity: inert supports (including zeolites and molecular sieves, etc.) and active supports (including CeO2, CuO, MnOx, etc.). Compared with the inert supports, active supports can not only realize the dispersion of Pt, but also play a role in the oxidation of VOCs. It has been reported that synergetic effect or the strong metal-support interaction between Pt NPs and the active support contributes to catalytic activity and stability in VOCs oxidation [21–24]. As an active component, MnOx is widely used in catalytic oxidation, and more and more researches have begun to focus on Pt-MnOx for catalytic oxidation of VOCs [23,25]. Duan et al. synthesized bi-component MnO2 and Mn3O4 supported Pt catalysts, and found that the superior catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst resulted from the high proportions of Pt° and fine interaction between Pt and MnO2@Mn3O4 at the interface [26]. Zhang et al. reported that strong oxidative hydroxyl radicals in Pt/MnO2 contributed to its excellent performance, achieving 100 % conversion of 0.42 ppm toluene at 28 °C under the gas-hourly-space-velocity of 300 L g−1 h−1 [27]. However, the studies on the reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation over Pt-MnOx catalysts are still not complete, especially how different oxygen species participate in the reaction, and the active site of the reaction is still unclear. Herein, we first synthesized Mn3O4-R by a facile reduction method, and then Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C were prepared by using Mn3O4-R and commercial Mn3O4 as the supports. Their catalytic performance in toluene oxidation were evaluated and it was found that the Pt/Mn3O4-R sample exhibited the highest activity for toluene oxidation. Then XRD, FESEM, HRTEM and CO pulse adsorption tests, etc. were performed to probe the crystal structure and textural properties, and H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS and O2 pulse adsorption tests were to measure the surface chemical states and redox properties. According to the characterization results above, TOFs based on possible active sites were calculated to clarify the active site controlling the reaction rate. Moreover, with the assistance of toluene-TPD, toluene-TPSR and in-situ DRIFTS, the participation of different oxygen species and the reaction pathway of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4 were illustrated in the present paper. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation All chemicals were of analytical grade, purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd and used as received without further purification. The sample denoted as Mn3O4-R was synthesized via a two-step reduction process. Briefly, 100 mL solution of KMnO4 (31.6 g/L) was dropped in the aqueous solution of oxalic acid (200 mL, 22.8 g/L) and the mixture was magnetically stirred for 3 h. Then the precipitates were collected by centrifugation. Subsequently, the solid product was reduced by aqueous solution of NaBH4 (10 mL, 8 g/L). Finally, the product was centrifuged, washed with deionized water, dried overnight and calcined at 400 ℃ for 2 h. And the other support denoted as Mn3O4-C was commercial. Pt/Mn3O4 was prepared by liquid-phase reduction method using NaBH4 as a reducing agent. Typically, 1 g Mn3O4 was dispersed in 20 mL solution of H2PtCl6 (1.07 mg/L) to reach a theoretical platinum load of 1% and the mixture was stirred for 3 h. Then, 10 mL of NaBH4 solution (8 g/L) was added dropwise into the foregoing mixture. After stirring for another three hours, the precipitates were centrifuged, washed with deionized water and dried overnight. The samples using Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-C as precursors were denoted as Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were collected on a D8 advance diffractometer equipped with a Cu Ka radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA from 2θ range of 10° to 80°. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was performed to examine the Pt loading on an Agilent ICP-OES730 instrument and a Meinhard nebulizer coupled to a cyclonic spray chamber were utilized to increase the analytical sensitivity. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded on an ASAP 2020 automated gas sorption system at −196 ℃. The specific surface areas (SBET) were calculated according to Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method from the adsorption. Raman spectra were collected on a LabRAM HR Evolution Laser Raman Spectrometer with the argon ion excitation source at 532 nm. The field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images were recorded by using a Zeiss Ultra at an accelerating voltage of 3 kV while those of high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) were on JEM-2100HR (JEOL, Japan). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 with Al Kα (hυ = 1486.8 eV) as the excitation source. By using the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV as an internal standard, the binding energy of all chemical species was calibrated. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed on a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920II chemisorption analyzer. 50 mg sample was pretreated at 300 ℃ for 1 h within a flow of O2/He (30 mL/min), then cooled down to 60 ℃ in an Argon flow (30 mL/min) and finally it was heated at a rate of 10 ℃/min from 60 to 600 ℃ in a flow of 5% H2/Ar (30 mL/min). The H2 consumption of all the catalysts was calculated by using CuO as a calibration reference. Oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) experiments were also carried out on a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920II chemisorption analyzer. 100 mg sample was pre-heated in 5% O2/He flow from room temperature to 300 ℃ and held for 1 h (30 mL/min), then cooled down to 60 ℃ in a pure helium flow (30 mL/min) and finally it was heated at a rate of 10 ℃/min from 60 to 800 ℃ in helium flow. The experiments of toluene temperature-programmed desorption (toluene-TPD) and toluene temperature programmed surface reaction (toluene-TPSR) were both performed on a ﬁxed-bed quartz reactor connected to a Hiden HPR-20 mass spectrometer. Typically, the samples were pretreated in the N2 flow at 300 ℃ for 1 h. After adsorption of toluene/N2 (1000 ppm) gas mixture for 1 h under ambient conditions, the gas flow was shifted to pure nitrogen and maintained for about 1 h. Then the reactor was heated to 500 ℃ with a linear step of 5 ℃/min. The experiments of toluene-TPSR were the same as that of toluene-TPD, except for mixing 1% of oxygen into the nitrogen flow while the reactor was heating to 500 ℃. During the aforementioned TPD and TPSR processes, toluene and CO2 were monitored with the m/z ratio of 92 and 44, respectively. The CO pulse adsorption test of the Pt supported samples were performed to determine the dispersion of platinum by using a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920II chemisorption analyzer. Typically, 0.1 g of the sample was pre-treated in a pure He flow (20 mL/min) at 200 ℃ for 2 h and then cooled down to room temperature. Then the pulse adsorption measurements were performed at this temperature with 10 % CO/He (20 mL/min). Oxygen pulse adsorption experiment was carried out on a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920II chemisorption analyzer to determine the value of oxygen storage capacity and to further calculate the surface oxygen vacancies. 100 mg sample was first reduced by 10 % H2/Ar at 200 ℃ for 2 h followed by cooling down to ambient temperature under helium flow. Subsequently a mixture gas flow of 10 % O2/He was periodically injected into the U-tube until absorption saturation. The oxygen consumption of the catalyst and the Pt species were defined as OSCcatalyst and OSCPt. The value of surface oxygen vacancies (OSCsurface) was calculated based on the following equation [28,29]: O S C P t = 2 D P t X P t M P t O S C s u r f a c e = O S C c a t a l y s t - O S C P t where DPt is the dispersion of Pt, determined by the result of CO pulse adsorption; XPt is the Pt loading of the catalyst; the stoichiometric factor between oxygen and Pt atom is set as 2:1, MPt denotes the molar weight of Pt (195.08 g mol−1). In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrometry (in-situ DRIFTS) was recorded on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA) equipped with an in-situ cell to detect the surface intermediate formed during toluene oxidation. The samples were pretreated by N2 (30 mL min−1) at the 300 ℃ for 1 h, followed by cooling down to room temperature, then designed gas flow was injected at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The background spectrum was collected in ﬂowing N2 and automatically subtracted from the sample spectrum at the corresponding temperature. In addition, in-situ DRIFTS spectra of toluene oxidation under different temperatures were recorded after 1 h balance at each temperature to ensure the adsorption-reaction equilibrium. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests Toluene oxidation reactions were performed on a ﬁxed-bed quartz reactor (6 mm i.d.). A mixture of air stream with a flow rate of 80 mL/min and toluene concentration of 1000 ppm was put in the reactor and passed over 100 mg of as prepared catalyst, resulting a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) at 48,000 mL g−1 h-1. All products were analyzed via an online gas chromatography (GC) (GC-2014C, Shimadzu) equipped with two flame ionization detectors (FID). Catalytic activities were evaluated using the temperatures (T50, and T90) required for achieving toluene conversions (Xtoluene) of 50, and 90 %, respectively, and the toluene conversion was calculated according to the following equations: X t o l u e n e = c t o l u e n e , i n - c t o l u e n e , o u t c t o l u e n e , i n × 100 % where ctoluene,out represented the outlet concentration of toluene at steady state, ctoluene,in was the inlet concentration of toluene. Two types of turnover frequencies (TOFs) were calculated based on the following equation [28]: T O F P t = X t o l u e n e F t o l u e n e M P t m c a t X P t D P t T O F O V = X t o l u e n e F t o l u e n e 1 m c a t O S C s u r f a c e where Xtoluene is the toluene conversion at a certain temperature; Ftoluene is the flow rate of toluene in unit of mol s−1; mcat is the mass of catalyst. TOFPt is the conventional calculation of turnover frequency based on the metal dispersion; TOFOV reflects the turnover frequency based on the concentration of oxygen vacancy on the surface of manganese oxide. In addition, the long-time stability test of the Pt/Mn3O4-R sample under different space velocity was performed by changing the flow rate of the gas mixture. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structure and textural properties Fig. 1 A shows the XRD patterns of as-prepared Mn3O4-based samples. The peaks of all catalysts could be indexed to the hausmannite Mn3O4 crystalline phase (JCPDS card No. 01-1127) and no obvious diffraction peak corresponding to Pt or PtOx phases was observed (as indicated in Fig. S1). Given the ICP-OES results that the actual platinum loading of Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C was 1.02 % and 0.95 % (very close to the theoretical loading), respectively, the absence of platinum peaks may be due to the low loading and high dispersion of platinum species. In addition, the diffraction peak intensities of Pt/Mn3O4-C were weaker than those of Mn3O4-C, indicating that the crystallinity of commercial manganese oxide became poorer during the loading process of platinum. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption tests were carried out and the results of different catalysts are presented in Fig. 1B and C. As shown in Fig. 1B, all samples exhibited typical IV isotherm with a H3 type hysteresis loops, suggesting the existence of mesopores. Combined with the pore size distribution in Fig. 1C, it could be inferred that the pores of all samples are mainly distributed in micropores and mesopores [9,30]. As listed in Table S1, the specific surface area of Pt/Mn3O4-R (90.0 m2/g) was much larger than that of Pt/Mn3O4-C (16.3 m2/g). Less crystallinity and larger specific surface area of Pt/Mn3O4-R are in favor to form more lattice defects and oxygen vacancies and introduce more active sites for toluene oxidation [32,33]. Comparing the specific surface area before and after loading of Pt, it was found that the specific surface area of the Mn3O4-R catalyst prepared by the reduction method decreased from 138.2 to 90.0 m2/g, while that of the commercial one slightly increased from 11.7 to 16.3 m2/g. Fig. 1D shows Raman spectra of four catalysts. Flat peaks could be observed at ca. 365 cm−1 and prominent peaks at ca. 640 cm−1 for Pt/Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 catalysts. The peaks at ca. 365 cm−1 were ascribed to the out-of-plane bending modes and those at ca. 640 cm−1 were attributed to symmetric stretch of Mn3O4, respectively [34,35]. It can be found that the intensity of the peaks at 640 cm−1 was in the order of Mn3O4-C > Pt/Mn3O4-C > Pt/Mn3O4-R > Mn3O4-R, which reflected the crystallinity and was in good agreement with the XRD results. In addition, the Mn-O force constant (k) can be calculated by the following formula [36,37]: ν = 1 2 π c k μ where ν is the wavenumber (cm−1), c is light velocity, and μ is the effective mass of the bond. The calculated force constant was in the order of Mn3O4-C (298.9 N/m) > Pt/Mn3O4-C (298.4 N/m) > Mn3O4-R (286.0 N/m) > Pt/Mn3O4-R (284.3 N/m). The force constant was related to the average Mn-O bond length by the equation k = 17/r3, so it can be deduced that Pt/Mn3O4-R exhibits the weakest Mn-O bonds among four catalysts. It has been reported that surface oxygen atoms in weak Mn-O bonds are more likely to be released to participate in oxidation, suggesting that the surface oxygen species of Pt/Mn3O4-R may perform the best mobility among as-prepared catalysts [38,39]. The FESEM and HRTEM images of different catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . The ordered block morphology of the Pt/Mn3O4-R is basically observed in Fig. 2A. Compared with the pure manganese oxide shown in Fig. 2C, the morphology of the Pt/Mn3O4-R catalyst was similar. Fig. 2B and D show that Pt/Mn3O4-C and Mn3O4-C both possess a square-pillow like morphology. While compared to Mn3O4-C, the crystal surface of Pt/Mn3O4-C was rougher and unevener, which may explain the decrease in crystallinity during the introduction of platinum to Mn3O4-C, in line with the results of XRD. The microscopic structures of Pt/Mn3O4 catalysts were probed by using the HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 2E and F. The lattice fringes of 0.275, 0.492 and 0.227 nm observed on Pt/Mn3O4-R in Fig. 2E were corresponded to the (103) and (101) crystal planes of Mn3O4 and (111) crystal planes of Pt, respectively. Correspondingly, the lattice fringes of 0.236 nm in Fig. 2F were assigned to the (004) crystal planes of Mn3O4 of Pt/Mn3O4-C catalyst. Moreover, CO pulse adsorption experiments were carried out to determine the dispersion of Pt. The dispersion of Pt for Pt/Mn3O4-R was 18.6 % and 8.4 % for Pt/Mn3O4-C, as listed in Table S1. The above results indicated that Pt on the surface of Pt/Mn3O4-R was better dispersed than that of Pt/Mn3O4-C. 3.2 Surface chemical states and redox properties For the purpose of investigating the redox properties of the as-synthesized catalysts, we performed the H2-TPR experiments, as shown in Fig. 3 . The small peaks of H2 consumption below 100 ℃ were associated with the reduction of PtOx species [17], and the broad peaks in the range from 150 to 500 ℃ were attributed to the stepwise reduction of Mn4+→Mn3+→Mn2+ under H2 flow [40]. Obviously, the H2-TPR profiles of Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-C were similar in shape with Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C, respectively, but after the introduction of Pt species, all the reduction peaks shifted to lower temperature regions. This may indicated the existence of a strong interaction between the Pt species and the MnOx support [14,23], which could result in weaker Mn-O bands thus promoting the oxygen mobility and forming more active oxygen species of supported platinum catalysts [25]. Furthermore, the main H2 consumption peak of Pt/Mn3O4-R was located in 198 ℃ and 272 ℃, lower than that of Pt/Mn3O4-C (270 ℃), suggesting that Pt/Mn3O4-R possessed the better low-temperature reducibility. By calculating the fitted area of spectrogram, it was found that Pt/Mn3O4-R consumed 4.62 mmol/g H2 below 250 ℃ in H2-TPR experiments, much more than that of Pt/Mn3O4-C (2.29 mmol/g), Mn3O4-R (1.58 mmol/g), and Mn3O4-C (0.07 mmol/g), suggesting the largest amount of reducible oxygen species, further indicating the best reducibility at relatively low temperature of Pt/Mn3O4-R [41,42]. The order of H2 consumption below 250 ℃ was in good consistency with catalytic performance (shown below), indicating catalytic activity is positively correlated with low temperature reducibility. O2-TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 4 . The spectrum of O2-TPD was divided into three regions in the temperature range from 60 to 800 ℃, that is, α, β, γ, corresponding to the desorption peaks at below 300, 300–460, and above 460 ℃ respectively. In general, the region α was attributed to the physically absorbed oxygen and weakly chemisorbed oxygen (O2−, O2 2−, or O-) that can easily desorb at low temperature, and regions β and γ corresponded to the desorption of surface lattice oxygen and bulk lattice oxygen [38,43,44]. Obviously, the amount of desorption in the α region exhibited a sequence of Mn3O4-R > Pt/Mn3O4-R > Pt/Mn3O4-C > Mn3O4-C and this was consistent with the result of specific surface area, illustrating the positive correlation between physical adsorption and specific surface area. In the region β, the desorption peak representing the surface lattice oxygen of Pt/Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-R appeared at 327 and 356 ℃. Compared with the commercial samples, the intensities of the desorption peak in the region β of Pt/Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-R was much greater. Besides, the peak positions of Pt/Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-R were at lower temperature than those of Pt/Mn3O4-C and Mn3O4-C. Greater intensity and lower desorption temperature of the surface lattice oxygen species indicated that Pt/Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-R possessed larger amount of surface lattice oxygen species of higher activity, which was beneficial for oxidation reaction [45,46]. In addition, the desorption peaks in the region β of Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C catalysts both shifted to lower temperature compare to pure manganese oxides catalysts, suggesting the introduction of Pt activated the surface lattice oxygen and improved its mobility. Surface chemical states of different samples were probed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technology. The XPS spectra of Pt 4f, Mn 3s, and O 1s of different samples are shown in Figs. 5, 6 and S2, respectively. The Pt 4f spectra in the range of 69–77 eV were divided into four peaks at 70.9, 73.9, 71.53 and 74.53 eV. The first two peaks were ascribed to the Pt° species and the latter two to Pt2+ species, respectively [13]. Obviously, the fitting peak area of Pt° was much larger than that of Pt2+, indicating that the platinum on the catalyst surface mainly existed in the form of Pt°. By calculating the area of each fitting peak, the ratio of Pt°/ (Pt°+Pt2+) was 81.4 % for Pt/Mn3O4-R and 80.3 % for Pt/Mn3O4-C. Although it has been revealed that the proportion of Pt° species have an impact on catalytic activity [16,17], the slight difference of Pt°/ (Pt°+Pt2+) ratio between Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C are within the analysis error. The average oxidation state (AOS) of the surface manganese was calculated based on the equation [47]: AOS = 8.956–1.126ΔEs, in which ΔEs represents the splitting width between two Mn 3 s peaks (Fig. S2). The corresponding AOS values were determined to be 2.63 for Pt/Mn3O4-R and 2.66 for Pt/Mn3O4-C. As discussed in the literatures, lower AOS meant the existence of more low-valent manganese ions, and more oxygen vacancies would be generated to maintain electrostatic balance [44,48], suggesting more surface oxygen vacancies on Pt/Mn3O4-R. To further obtain the concentration of surface oxygen vacancy quantificationally, oxygen pulse adsorption test was carried out. The value of oxygen vacancies was obtained after deducting the OSCPt value from OSCcatalyst. The surface oxygen vacancies of Pt/Mn3O4-R was determined to be 0.076 mmol/g, much larger than that of Pt/Mn3O4-C (0.045 mmol/g), illustrating more oxygen vacancies on the surface of Pt/Mn3O4-R and more oxygen adsorption sites for toluene oxidation. Oxygen vacancies were reported to be conducive to the adsorption and activation of molecular oxygen, remarkably influencing the catalytic activity of toluene oxidation [21,49]. In addition, the O 1s XPS spectra were displayed in Fig. 6, and three kinds of oxygen species could be clearly found from deconvolution. These bands can be ascribed to surface lattice oxygen (Olatt at ca. 529.6 eV), surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads at ca. 531 eV), and hydroxyl oxygen or oxygen from water (OH2O+OH at ca. 532 eV), respectively [50,51]. It has been revealed that the Oads species play a crucial role in the catalytic oxidation reaction. The percentage of Oads was calculated to be 28.1 % for Pt/Mn3O4-R and 25.5 % for Pt/Mn3O4-C (Table 1 ), suggesting the better catalytic prosperity of Pt/Mn3O4-R than Pt/Mn3O4-C [52,53]. 3.3 Catalytic activity and investigation into active site The catalytic performance of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R, Pt/Mn3O4-C, Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-C were estimated under a weight hourly space velocity of 48,000 mL g−1 h−1, as shown in Fig. 7 A. The toluene conversion increased with temperature rising. As for Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-C samples, Mn3O4-R catalyst had higher activity for toluene oxidation, achieving T50 and T90 at 261 and 279 ℃. After Pt species was loaded on the support, the activity performance of the catalyst significantly improved. Pt/Mn3O4-R sample reached 50 % conversion at 172 ℃ and 90 % conversion at 183 ℃. It exhibited much higher catalytic activity than Pt/Mn3O4-C, which converted 50 % toluene at 201 ℃ and 90 % toluene at 226 ℃. Obviously, the introduction of Pt was one of the reasons why toluene catalytic performance of Pt/Mn3O4-R is better than three other catalysts. Therefore, Pt/Mn3O4-R catalyst with different Pt loadings were prepared and their catalytic evaluation curves are shown in Fig. 7B. As the Pt content increased, the temperature catalyst achieving complete degradation of toluene decreased from 210 to 180 ℃. However, it had been reported that in the toluene oxidation over catalysts where Pt was loaded on active supports, the active sites that control the reaction rate are surface oxygen vacancies instead of exposed Pt atoms [17,28]. In the present work, the main factors leading to the difference in reactivity was probable the proportion of Pt° species, the dispersion of Pt, and the concentration of oxygen vacancies. Since the proportion of Pt° species between Pt/Mn3O4- R and Pt/Mn3O4-C was not much different, it cannot explain the huge difference in activity between Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C. In order to further explore the active sites, the TOFs based on Pt dispersion and surface oxygen vacancies were calculated at 150 ℃, and the results are listed in Table 2 . The value of TOFOV is 7.56 × 10−8 s−1 for Pt/Mn3O4-R and 7.62 × 10−8 s−1 for Pt/Mn3O4-C, which was quite close. While the TOFPt between Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C at 150 ℃ were different. That meant the surface oxygen vacancies were the main active sites controlling the reaction rate at 150 ℃. It has been reported that for the VOCs oxidation reaction over catalysts where noble metals are loaded on active supports, the reaction follows a dual site mechanism. Specifically, the reaction rate is controlled by two steps: the oxygen chemisorption process on the surface vacancies and reaction between oxidized VOCs intermediate and adsorbed oxygen controlled by noble metals [17,54–56]. O2-TPD results in Fig. 4 have shown that the desorption of physically absorbed oxygen and weakly chemisorbed oxygen was at the temperature of ca. 100 ℃. The temperature of 150 ℃ was not conducive to the progress of chemical adsorption and activation on oxygen vacancies, so oxygen vacancies were possible the active sites that controlled the reaction rate at 150 ℃. In addition, stability tests of the catalyst with the best performance were carried out. The cycling test and XRD results of used catalyst are shown in Fig. 7C and Fig. S3, respectively. It was found that the catalytic activity and crystal phase of Pt/Mn3O4-R was basically maintained during the reuse tests, indicating its good stability in repeated utilization. The long-term test under different space velocity shown in Fig. 7D demonstrated that the catalyst was stable over a long period of time, and it could still maintain a conversion rate of 60 % at a high space velocity of 80,000 mL g−1 h−1. 3.4 Mechanistic investigation of toluene oxidation 3.4.1 Mechanistic investigation by toluene-TPD and toluene-TPSR In order to determine the participation of gaseous oxygen and lattice oxygen in the catalytic oxidation of toluene over Pt/Mn3O4 and Mn3O4, toluene-TPD and toluene-TPSR tests were carried out. Fragments of m/z = 92 and m/z = 44 were used to identify toluene and the formed CO2, respectively. The mass signal of toluene in toluene-TPD test is shown in Fig. 8 A, obvious peaks were observed in the range of 50–150 ℃ on Pt/Mn3O4-R, Pt/Mn3O4-C and Mn3O4-R, which can be attributed to the desorption of physically adsorbed toluene [39,57]. The desorption amount of toluene followed the sequence of Mn3O4-R > Pt/Mn3O4-R>> Pt/Mn3O4-C > Mn3O4-C, confirming that Pt/Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-R exhibited stronger ability to adsorb toluene than Pt/Mn3O4-C and Mn3O4-C. Meanwhile, CO2 was also formed over some catalysts during toluene-TPD experiments (Fig. 8B). It was worth mentioning that the catalyst was heated in nitrogen atmosphere at 300 ℃ for one hour to remove the gas-phase oxygen adsorbed on the surface in the pretreatment, so the CO2 produced during toluene-TPD experiments originated from the reaction between the lattice oxygen species of manganese oxides and chemically adsorbed toluene [39]. As showed in Fig. 8B, dotted lines and solid lines represented the mass signal of CO2 (m/z = 44) that toluene was oxidized over the catalyst in the absence and presence of gaseous oxygen, respectively. The CO2 peaks of Pt/Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-R were centered on 279 and 317 ℃ in toluene-TPD tests. Compared with Mn3O4-R, the peak position of Pt/Mn3O4-R shifted to a lower temperature. This result illustrated that the lattice oxygen in Pt/Mn3O4-R could oxidize toluene at lower temperature, suggesting in addition to the activation of toluene by Pt species, the introduction of Pt could promote the activity of surface/subsurface lattice oxygen, which was in agreement with the result of O2-TPD. In the absence of gaseous oxygen, the starting temperature of CO2 peak of Pt/Mn3O4-R is 202 ℃, while in the presence of gaseous oxygen, the starting temperature was shifted to 180 ℃. This indicated that gas phase oxygen could replenish the lattice oxygen by the oxygen vacancies, facilitate the circulation of oxygen and promote the reaction of ad-toluene with the oxygen species of Mn3O4 [26,58]. It was reasonable to deduce that toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R catalyst in the presence of gaseous oxygen followed the Mars–van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism. And for toluene over Pt/Mn3O4-C catalyst, almost no distinct peak of CO2 was detected on Pt/Mn3O4-C in the absence of gaseous oxygen although their CO2 signal was amplified by 5 times. However, the sharp peak of CO2 was observed to start at 189 ℃ and center on 201 ℃ over Pt/Mn3O4-C in toluene-TPSR, indicating that the absence of CO2 production in toluene-TPD over Pt/Mn3O4-C was due to the poor lattice oxygen species instead of too little chemisorbed toluene. The above results of toluene-TPD and toluene-TPSR demonstrated that the amount and mobility of lattice oxygen had a great influence on the reaction mechanism, and the lattice oxygen with high activity and strong mobility is the premise of MVK mechanism. 3.4.2 Mechanistic investigation by in-situ DRIFTS The in-situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted to further investigate the mechanism and to determine the adsorption intermediates during toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R, Pt/Mn3O4-C and Mn3O4-R. The results of in-situ DRIFTS under different situation are depicted in Fig. 9 and the details about assignment of infrared bands are listed in Table 3 . Fig. 9A shows the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of toluene adsorption over Pt/Mn3O4-R at 180 ℃ under 500 ppm toluene/air for 0, 20, 40, 60, 80 and 100 min. The peak intensity of these peaks gradually became stronger with time and stabilized at about 100 min, indicating that the toluene oxidation reaction reached dynamic equilibrium at this time. The strong bands at 1593, 1529, and 1492 cm−1 could be assigned to out-of-plane and in-plane vibrations of aromatic ring [32,59], and those at 1513 and 1448 cm-1 was attributed to skeletal CC stretching vibration of aromatic ring [39], suggesting the significant existence of adsorbed original toluene and other intermediate before the aromatic ring opening. The peaks located at 1562, 1546 and 1413 cm−1 could be assigned to carboxylate species, indicating the existence of benzoate species [10]. Notably, the bands at around 1402 cm−1 were mainly attributed to ν (COO) vibrations, indicating the accumulation of surface manganese carbonate species [33,60,61]. Combining the species above, it could be inferred that toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R probably followed the pathway of toluene → benzoate → carbonate → CO2 in the presence of gaseous oxygen. In-situ DRIFTS of toluene adsorption over Pt/Mn3O4-R under 500 ppm toluene/N2 at 180 ℃ for different time was performed, as shown in Fig. 9B. The benzoic acid and carbonate species were still detected in Fig. 9B, illustrating that in the absence of gas phase oxygen, the surface lattice oxygen could deeply oxide toluene over Pt/Mn3O4-R at 180 ℃, which was in good agreement with the results of toluene-TPD. In addition to the absorption peaks that have appeared in Fig. 9A, several new peaks was also detected, that was the bands located at 1178 and 1025 cm−1(characteristic of CO stretching vibration of alkoxide species), and the bands at 1652 and 1473 cm−1(characteristic of CO stretching vibration of aldehydes), suggesting a small differences in toluene oxidation path from that in Fig. 9A [32]. This showed that gas phase oxygen was a key factor in promoting the conversion of benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid. The absorption peak intensity in Fig. 9A was much stronger than that in Fig. 9B, which meant that the reaction rate of toluene oxidation in the presence of gaseous oxygen was much higher than that in the absence of gaseous oxygen. This might be because gas phase oxygen supplemented lattice oxygen and facilitate the circulation of oxygen, thus greatly increasing the oxidation rate of toluene. To realize the participation of lattice oxygen, the in-situ DRIFTS over Pt/Mn3O4-C which exhibited worse mobility of lattice oxygen were performed and the results are shown in Fig. 9C, D, and E. Similar to the spectra in Fig. 9A and B, benzoate species (1564, 1537 and 1427 cm−1) and benzaldehyde species (1652 and 1473 cm−1) were detected over the surface of Pt/Mn3O4-C sample. Obviously, there was no IR absorption peak of carbonate in any of Fig. 9C, D, and E, even if the temperature was elevated to 220 ℃ shown in Fig. 9E. This illustrated that the oxidation of toluene over Pt/Mn3O4-C might follow a reaction path of toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid → CO2, which was different from that over Pt/Mn3O4-R. On the other hand, it also demonstrated that the active lattice oxygen species could be the prerequisite for the conversion of intermediate products such as benzoic acid to carbonate. Compared to 10B, the peak intensity in 10D was lower and the peak area was smaller, indicating that lattice oxygen could still play a significant role on toluene oxide in the absence of gas phase oxygen. This was consistent with the results of toluene-TPD. Platinum was a crucial factor in the catalytic oxidation of toluene, and to understand the role of platinum, in-situ DRIFTS experiment of toluene oxidation reaction over Mn3O4-R at 180 ℃ under 500 ppm toluene/air for different time was carried out. As depicted in Fig. 9F, benzoate species (1558, 1540 and 1417 cm−1), benzyl alcohol species (1178 and 1025 cm−1), benzaldehyde species (1652 and 1473 cm−1) and carbonate species (1396 cm−1) were detected over the surface of Mn3O4-R sample. Compared with Fig. 9A, benzoic acid and carbonate species were observed, as well as aldehyde species and alcohol species that were not in Fig. 9A. This was because the loading process of Pt improved the mobility of lattice oxygen, which has been confirmed by the result of O2-TPD, so increasing the supply of surface lattice oxygen, so that toluene could be directly oxidized into benzoic acid species in one step. Moreover, similar intermediate products indicated that toluene oxidation reaction over Pt/Mn3O4-R and Mn3O4-R might share a similar reaction pathway. The intensity of peaks in Fig. 9F was weaker than that in Fig. 9A and C, indicating that the oxidation rate of toluene on the surface of the platinum-supported catalyst was significantly increased. Fig. 9F depicted significantly stronger absorption peaks of benzoic acid species and fewer carbonate species, showing that toluene on Pt/Mn3O4-R is oxidized to a deeper degree than that on Mn3O4-R. This may be due to the active surface lattice oxygen brought by the introduction of Pt, which promoted the conversion of further degradation of benzoic acid. Based on the above DRIFTS spectra analyses, it can be concluded that the mobility of lattice oxygen on catalyst and gaseous oxygen both affected the reaction path of toluene oxidation, while gas phase oxygen and the introduction of Pt have a great influence on the reaction rate and depth of toluene reaction. It has been put forward by Yang et al. [39] that the decomposition of carbonate was the possible rate-controlling step of toluene oxidation over MnOx. In this study, the absorption peak of carbonate species exhibited great intensity in Fig. 9A, and we assumed that the decomposition of carbonate was the rate-controlling step of toluene oxidation over the Pt/Mn3O4-R. Hence, in-situ DRIFTS experiments of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R exposed to 500 ppm toluene/air under different temperatures (Fig. 10 A) and the test of oxidation process of pre-adsorbed toluene at 180 ℃ for 100 min under nitrogen atmosphere over Pt/Mn3O4-R (Fig. 10C) were performed. It can be seen from Fig. 10A that as the temperature increased, the absorption peaks of each intermediate products became enhanced, indicating the increase of oxidation rate. The characteristic peak intensities of the four substances were sorted in Fig. 10B. It could be seen that the signal values of alcohol (1178 cm−1), aldehyde (1479 cm−1), and benzoic acid (1546 cm−1) gradually increased, and that of carbonate (1402 cm−1) reached the peak value at 180 ℃ and then weakened, indicating that the consumption rate of carbonate was low at low temperature and increased greatly after 180 ℃. Furthermore, Fig. 10C and D show the gradual oxidation process of pre-adsorbed toluene and other intermediates. The characteristic peak intensities of alcohol, aldehyde, and benzoic acid all gradually decreased while that of carbonate has experienced a process of increasing first and then decreasing, indicating that the decomposition rate of carbonate at low temperature was lower than the rate that new carbonate was formed by upstream products, thus leading to the accumulation of carbonate. The above results indicated that the decomposition of carbonate species to CO2 might be the rate-controlling step of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R at 180–200 ℃. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Pt/Mn3O4-R was synthesized by a facile approach and exhibited high catalytic performance (T90 = 183 ℃) as well as good stability in cycling and high space velocity tests. H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS, O2 pulse adsorption demonstrated that compared with the Pt/Mn3O4-C using the commercial Mn3O4, Pt/Mn3O4-R had much more surface oxygen vacancies and exhibited better dispersion of platinum particles, resulting in its excellent activity for toluene oxidation. Through toluene-TPD, toluene-TPSR and in-situ DRIFTS, it was reasonable to predict that toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R catalyst in the presence of gaseous oxygen followed the Mars–van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism and the pathway of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R might be toluene → benzoate → carbonate → CO2. The introduction of Pt improved the activity of lattice oxygen and the redox prosperity of the catalyst, which are in favor to reduce the temperature of surface lattice oxygen being utilized, increase the reaction rate of toluene oxidation, and promote the deep oxidation of toluene. The amount and mobility of lattice oxygen species on the surface of catalysts was found to greatly affected the reaction mechanism and pathway. The gaseous oxygen could replenish the lattice oxygen by adsorbing on the oxygen vacancies, facilitate the circulation of oxygen and promote the reaction of ad-toluene with the oxygen species of Mn3O4. In addition, the decomposition of carbonate was confirmed to be the controlling step of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R at 180–200 ℃. coredata.dc:description: With the aim to elucidate the roles of different oxygen species, the catalytic oxidation of toluene over Pt/Mn3O4 synthesized by a facile reduction method was investigated. Compared with the Pt/Mn3O4-C using the commercial Mn3O4 as the support, Pt/Mn3O4-R was found to possess more surface oxygen vacancies, exhibit better redox properties and dispersion of platinum particles, leading to its higher activity for toluene oxidation (T90 = 183 ℃). Through toluene-TPD, toluene-TPSR and in-situ DRIFTS, it was found that toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R catalyst might follow the Mars–van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism and the pathway of toluene oxidation over Pt/Mn3O4-R was possible toluene → benzoate → carbonate → CO2. The lattice oxygen species on the surface of catalysts was directly involved in the oxidation of toluene and played an important role in the formation of key intermediate such as carbonate, resulting in the difference of the reaction mechanism and pathway between Pt/Mn3O4-R and Pt/Mn3O4-C. In addition, the degradation of the surface carbonate was demonstrated to be the rate-controlling step at 180℃ to 200℃.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation into the roles of different oxygen species in toluene oxidation over manganese-supported platinum catalysts
